Jim, Great tsuba. Nice to have that kind of provenance, gives it 
that litt=
le bit extra. John



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <j=
ggilbert@...> 
wrote:
>
> I have added scans of the other side of the tsuba=
 to the folder 
below.  I forgot to mention the dimensions again, so for th=
e record 
they are 90.1 mm H x 84.1 mm W x 5.0 - 5.5 mm thick at the mimi.
=
> 
> The maker is Nobuie and the signature is of the type now called 
futoj=
i-mei =E5=A4=AA=E5=AD=97=E9=8A=98 (bold, thick).  Within both the hanare an=
d 
futoji-mei types there is considerable variation in the detail of 
the s=
ignatures.  This example is not one of the more boldly executed 
futoji-mei=
.  As Pete crypictically indicated, an oshigata of this 
guard is published=
 in Nakamura Kakudayu and Akiyama Kyusaku's 1926 
Nobuie Tsuba shu (#52).  =
There the signature is described as sumari-
mei =E8=A9=B0=E3=82=8A=E9=8A=98=
 ("close packed"), which is one of the older terms now 
included within the=
 futoji-mei type.  This guard is described as 
futoji-mei in several later =
books and in the NBTHK's attribution.
> 
> The hitsuana had not yet been fi=
lled when the oshigata was made.  
This guard was the property of the Okubo=
 daimyo family in Odawara 
until it was sold in 1931, so the ana were likel=
y filled by the new 
owner.  It is unlikely that they are original to the p=
late given 
that they are made such that the guard would be mounted with th=
e 
unsigned side as the front.  The shapes of the hitsuana are 
unusual.   =
It was clearly mounted with an o-kozuka, which are 
typically 18-20 mm wide=
 (vs. the standard size of 14-15 mm).  As 
Gordon mentioned, the small size=
 of the kogai-ana suggests it was 
mounted with one of the narrow style ko-=
Mino kogai.  The opening is 
too small to accommodate a standard 14-15 mm w=
ide kogai.
> 
> The early Edo period "betsujin" (different person) Nobuie w=
ork 
will lack the quality in the metal, tekkotsu, finish and carving.  
Th=
e plates are usually rather characterless and the working lacks 
subtlety. =
 The late Edo period revival pieces do indeed try to 
emulate the finish of=
 the originals and as Alan mentioned some do a 
fairly good job.  In genera=
l, the working of the rim is a bit forced 
and overdone in these examples c=
ompared to the originals.  They 
obviously will look young, but there is al=
so a somewhat artificial 
quality to them.  The same feeling comes from lat=
er copies of early 
Shino and Oribe ceramics.
> 
> The metal, tekkotsu and =
yakite finish should lead to an Owari 
origin.  Remember that Kaneie worked=
 in Kyoto, and everything about 
his guards is in line with Kyoto methods a=
nd aesthetics.
> 
> That's all I can think of at the moment.
> 
> Jim  
> 
=
>
